## What is the current behavior?
Currently, the most used way by developers to define validation messages in form fields is in HTML itself. With that in mind, I decided to add a new parameter to the Validator's methods, making it possible to add a specific message to the field in the form itself.

#### Creating the form:
```
this.personForm = this.fb.group({
  name: ['', [Validators.minLength(3), Validators.required]],
  age: ['', Validators.min(18)],
});
```

#### Getting validation message:
```
<small *ngIf="form.get('name').hasError('required')">Name is required</small>
```

Issue Number: #43423


## What is the new behavior?

####Creating the form:
```
this.personForm = this.fb.group({
  name: ['', [Validators.minLength(3), Validators.required('Required message')]],
  age: ['', Validators.min(18, 'Min. message')],
});
```

####Getting validation message:
```
<small *ngIf="form.get('name').hasError('required')">
  {{ form.get("name").getError("required").message }}
</small>
```

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

#### BREAKING CHANGES
Change in syntax of required, requiredTrue and email validators.
Now the syntaxes have changed, and it is mandatory to add the parentheses for these methods, for example:

* 'Validators.required' to 'Validators.required()';
* 'Validators.requiredTrue' to 'Validators.requiredTrue()';
* 'Validators.email' to 'Validators.email()';

Issues.Title: Navigating to an Angular Route from AngularJS (Hybrid) runs Resolvers and Guards twice
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

router

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

[#45240](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/45240) Specifically removed some logic that was responsible for preventing duplicate navigation in hybrid apps, stating that

> There have been many updates to the routing pipeline to tolerate
duplicate navigations. That is, duplicate navigations can happen and
routing should still complete successfully.

The problem with this is that, when this duplicate navigation occurs, all angular resolves and guards are running twice for the route.  As a result of upgrading to @angular/router@13.2.6, all of our resolves are running twice, making duplicate server requests for many of our pages. In one instance where this was found, it actually completely broke navigation as the second network request of the same payload will always error out.

Issues.Title: fix(core): deduplicate imports of standalone components in JIT compiler
Issues.Body:
During JIT compilation of standalone components the compiler did not deduplicate
declarations in the imports array, unlike the AOT compiler. This may result in
runtime errors during directive matching, when the same component is found
multiple times resulting in NG0300, for example:

> NG0300: Multiple components match node with tagname mat-form-field: MatFormField and MatFormField.

This commit fixes the issue by deduplicating imports in the JIT compiler.

Relates to https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/46109#issuecomment-1160705031

Closes #46109

Issues.Title: Missing docs on expected service worker behavior
Issues.Body:
### Description

I have an Angular PWA app, and I run a PUT request in my app. It receives a 504 response (from the service worker) when not online. I'm trying to figure out what's causing this, and if that's expected behavior from the service worker, but I can't find anything in the docs about this.

[This](https://angular.io/guide/service-worker-config#urls) documentation says:

> A list of URL patterns. URLs that match these patterns are cached according to this data group's policy. Only non-mutating requests (GET and HEAD) are cached.

This leads me to think that a PUT request will be relayed through the service worker to the API (but not cached), and that the response also will on the way back.

What really happens is that the service worker responds with a 504 Gateway Timeout. If I bypass the service worker, I get a status code 0 (which is what I was expecting because I read it somewhere in the Angular docs I think, though I can't find it again).

Can anyone shed some light on how one is supposed to handle detecting that the app is missing connection?
- Are you supposed to bypass the service worker to be able to detect this?
- If not, is a 504 response code from the service worker expected for a PUT method when offline? Or am I missing something?
- Is 504 a better way of detecting network issues than 0 (as it seems like code 0 is a generic error code)?

It would be great if this behavior would be documented on the referred page. If this isn't related to the Angular implementation of the service worker, but more a question about how service workers are supposed to work in general, let me know. I couldn't find any good resources on the subject.

Issues.Title: Wrong FormControl type inference when created with FormBuild through group() with Validators and an array as value
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When creating a FormGroup with the new ng14 FormBuilder, if you try to add a control with both array value and validator(s) the infered type for this control become wrong. It seems the validator(s) are considered as value so we get a bad union typing.

```ts
/**
 * Wrong type!
 * FormGroup<{
 *   test: FormControl<number[] | ((control: AbstractControl<any, any>) => ValidationErrors | null)>;
 *  }>
 */
const form = fb.nonNullable.group({
  test: [[1,2,3], Validators.required]
})
```

If you use the long way to add control, everything works just fine but we loose FormBuilder.group() shorthand synthax benefit

```ts
/**
 * Good type!
 * FormGroup<{
 *   test: FormControl<number[]>;
 *  }>
 */
const form = fb.nonNullable.group({
  test: fb.nonNullable.control([1,2,3], Validators.required)
})
```

This worked in v13 of the CLI ### Description We are working on updating our ng deploy schematic for Angular 14, unfortunately some command line arguments are no longer detected correctly. Arguments like `noBuild`, `noSilent`, `noDotFiles` no longer work, but `buildTarget` and `dryRun` do. I assume this is related with https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/22778 and the fact that Yargs supports `--no-flags`. In the past, the word `no` had no meaning, now it has one: https://github.com/yargs/yargs/blob/main/docs/tricks.md#negate In Angular 13 i was able write `no-build` as an argument and it was used as it-is, but now this is interpreted as the negation of `build` – which is an unknown argument. This breaks a couple of builders that all share some code/ideas and use the same argument called `no-build`. * [@netlify-builder/deploy](https://github.com/ngx-builders/netlify-builder/blob/b915395041d61d460f3a312c1a9c7cc9a683cda2/src/deploy/schema.json#L17) * [angular-cli-ghpages](https://github.com/angular-schule/angular-cli-ghpages#no-build) * as well as [ngx-deploy-docker](https://github.com/kauppfbi/ngx-deploy-docker), [ngx-deploy-npm](https://github.com/bikecoders/ngx-deploy-npm), and [ngx-deploy-ftp](https://github.com/bohoffi/ngx-deploy-ftp) * there could be more... ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Please follow our [README for contributors](https://github.com/angular-schule/angular-cli-ghpages/blob/master/docs/README_contributors.md), which is essentially: 1. - Use `autoFocus: false` → no difference :x:

Issues.Title: feat(material/legacy-core): create legacy-core entry point
Issues.Body:
Sets up @angular/material/legacy-core as a location to aggregate legacy themes as components are replaced by their MDC-based versions.

Also establishes @angular/material's dependency on MDC and moves mdc-helpers to @angular/material/core in preparation for moving MDC based components out of experimental

Notable changes:
- The "all-theme" mixins (`mat.all-component-themes`, `mat.all-component-typographies`, `mat.all-component-colors`, and `mat.all-component-densities`) have been split into a legacy (living under material/legacy-core) and non-legacy (living under material/core) version. In addition the MDC version living under `material-experimental/mdc-core` still exists as well. The plan when moving MDC components out of material-experimental is:
   1. The non MDC theme should be moved from core all-themes to legacy-core all-themes
   2. The MDC theme should be added to core all-themes
   3. The mdc-core version of all-themes should continue to include all MDC themes, even those moved out of experimental
- Since `mat.core` includes typography styles, it too has been split into a legacy and non-legacy versions that call out to their corresponding all-typographies mixin.
- Since the prebuilt files are also based on the all-theme mixins, they too have been split into legacy and non-legacy versions
- `mat.mdc-strong-focus-indicators` and related theme mixins have been rolled into their non-MDC counterparts, and the MDC version of the mixins deleted. There's no reason to have them be separate mixins now that they live in the same package

Issues.Title: build: avoid use of `yarn ts-node` to avoid nested yarn execution
Issues.Body:
We can directly use `ts-node` to avoid printing errors twice when
the nested execution fails.

e.g.

```
Not enough non-option arguments: got 0, need at least 1
error Command failed with exit code 1.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.
error Command failed with exit code 1.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.
```
